div.head: Drawings from the Tour of 1833
div.p: Drawings that Ruskin made during the Tour of 1833—and possibly, some of them, after the familyʼs return home—are listed below in topographical order, according to the tour itinerary. I am grateful to Stephen Wildman for the basis of this list, which draws on holdings in libraries and galleries and on listings in catalogues.

Significantly more 1833 drawings have been documented than can presently be traced. Whether known only by a catalogue entry or accessible in a collection, however, examples span the scope of the Tour of 1833, highlighting the entrance to the Continent though northern France and Belgium; the Rhine journey; the passage through the Alps to northern Italy; the circle through Switzerland; and the return home via France. The surviving drawing from earliest in the tour--a Proutesque pencil treatment of Hotel de Ville, Cassel--was not the first scene to be drawn. Ruskin's cousin, Mary Richardson, recorded in her travel diary that, on their first evening in Calais, "John and I drew a little before dinner a part of [the] sitting room" of their hotel, which she thought "a very handsome room, quite French" (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 2).

div.head: The Relation of the Tour Sketches to Illustrations for Account of a Tour on the Continent
div.p: Omitted from this list are the drawings that Ruskin made to illustrate Account of a Tour on the Continent, which occupied his creative energy for about a year following the familyʼs return in September 1833 (see “Account”: Date). The illustrations are annotated separately as part of ERMʼs edition of the “Account”. The tour sketches are distinct from the “Account” illustrations in style and other features, even though Ruskin used the tour sketches as the basis for some of the vignette-style illustrations, as explained in Account of a Tour on the Continent: Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue (MS IX) and Related 1833 Tour Sketches. The “Account” illustrations should be understood less as records of a tour, than as imitations of the visual media of the 1830s, whereby British readers consumed Continental scenery through the print culture of the period. Ruskin himself makes this distinction in Praeterita, when reviewing his 1833 drawings: "With these flying scrawls on the road", he wrote, referring to the tour sketches, "I made, when staying in towns, some elaborate pencil and pen outlines, of which perhaps half-a-dozen are worth register and preservation. My father's pride in a study of the doubly-towered Renaissance church of Dijon was great. A still more laborious Hôtel de Ville of Brussels remains with it at Brantwood. The drawing of that Hôtel de Ville by me now at Oxford", he added, referring to one of the drawings related to the “Account” project, "is a copy of Prout's, which I made in illustration of the volume in which I wrote the beginning of a rhymed history of the tour" (Ruskin, Works, 35:80-81).

div.head: Confusions in Cataloguing the Tour Sketches and the Illustrations for the "Account"
div.p: Despite this distinction between sources and style of the tour sketches and the illustrations, an attempt to list the tour sketches from 1833 will likely perpetuate some confusion in earlier catalogues between the two kinds of drawings, which can no longer be sorted out, since too little is known about drawings that cannot be traced. Drawings presumed to have been tour sketches may have been versions reworked for use in the fair‐copy “Account” (MS IX), but which became separated from the manuscript or were never permanently affixed there. Confusion arises, for example, in tracing the drawings of the Hôtel de Ville, Brussels, that Ruskin mentions in Praeterita. The "laborious" tour-sketch version does bear a consistent provenance, traceable in the Library Edition from Brantwood to the Manchester Ruskin Exhibition (1904); this drawing is now held by the Pierpont Morgan Library (see Ruskin, Works, 35:81 n. 1; 38:236). The "still more laborious" copy of Prout's lithograph view, Hotel de Ville Brussells, from Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany, is probably the same drawing that Ruskin exhibited at the Fine Art Society (1878). In the catalogue for that exhibition, “Notes on My Own Drawings and Engravings”, he describes the drawing as a copy after Prout, and not as an on-the-site tour sketch (Notes by Mr. Ruskin on His Drawings by the Late J. M. W. Turner, R.A., in Ruskin, Works, 13:505). This drawing appears to be the same as one now held by the Ruskin Library, Lancaster (Hôtel de Ville, Brussels, after Samuel Prout); and it would be logical to associate this drawing with the MS IX fair copy of the "Account", which does present a blank gap above the header for the section, “Brussels”. The Lancaster drawing, however, is too large to have been tipped into this gap in MS IX, whereas a drawing more likely to have been intended for that space emerges in the provenance record as a possible miniature" version of Ruskinʼs copy after Prout, which was exhibited at the Ruskin Memorial Exhibition, Mechanics' Institute, Coniston (1900). The location of this drawing is unknown; and its catalogue description by W. G. Collingwood is ambiguous (see, for further discussion, Hôtel de Ville, Brussels; see also Missing and Unidentified Drawings for the Composite‐Genre Illustrated Travelogue [MS IX] and Related 1833 Tour Sketches). Such confusion seem to beset the cataloguing of drawings especially from the 1833 tour, because of their near relation to Ruskin's production of illustrations for "Account" in 1833-34. Despite this caveat, in both the 1830s and the 1870s-80s, Ruskin maintained a distinction between his tour sketching and his imitation of illustrated travel literature--the latter entailing, at least in the case of the Hôtel de Ville drawings, an elaborate exploration of visual media, which led Ruskin first to copy Prout on the scale of a lithograph, and then to reduce that copy to the scale of a steel-engraved vignette.

Another source of obscurity in distinguishing the tour sketches from the illustrations for the "Account" may lie, not only with an inability to identify a catalogued work and trace it to its current location, but also with errors or duplications in the cataloguing itself. For example, according to the “Catalogue of Ruskinʼs Drawings” compiled for the Library Edition, an 1833 item, Sketches, Vignettes of Italian Scenes, was exhibited at the Ruskin Memorial Exhibition, Mechanicsʼ Institute, Coniston (1900), referencing no. 7 in the catalogue of the exhibition, Collingwood, Ruskin Exhibition. (Ruskin, Works, 38:259 [no. 898]). Collingwood's catalogue entry for no. 7 reads, however, "Sheet of vignettes, redrawn from sketches in North Italy, 1833", which is nearly identical to a separately titled entry in the Library Edition catalogue--namely, A Sheet of Vignettes, Re‐drawn from Sketches in N. Italy (Ruskin, Works, 38:304 [no. 2100]). Did the editors of the Library Edition create two separate entries for the same item? The latter entry compounds the mystery by associating the item with a different exhibition history--not with the Coniston Exhibition, but with the Ruskin Exhibition, Manchester (1904), citing no. 6 in the Manchester City Art Gallery, Catalogue of the Ruskin Exhibition. The present location of neither item is known. Further research may reveal a connection between either or both of these catalogue items, moreover, with a drawing that does survive in a collection, Sheet of Six Swiss and Italian Views, held by the Boston Museum of Fine Arts.

At least two drawings designated as 1833 in the “Catalogue of Ruskinʼs Drawings” are misdated. Landeck (pencil)--listed as no. 939 in Ruskin, Works, 38:260, and credited to the Cunliffe collection)--cannot have been produced during the 1833 tour, since that journey did not include the Tyrol. The date of this drawing is corrected to 21 September 1835 and identified in Hanley and Hull, ed., John Ruskinʼs Continental Tour 1835, 228 (no. 96).

A second misdated drawing is St. Radeguneʼs Abbey [i.e., St. Radegundʼs], which the editors of the Library Edition identified as an 1833 drawing on the basis of Ruskin's mention of the sketch in Fors Clavigera as “the first ‘remaining’ of Antiquity I ever sketched, when a boy of fourteen” (letter 27 [27 January 1873], Ruskin, Works, 27:492; and see Ruskin, Works, 38:280 [no. 1468]). If Ruskin meant that the sketch represented his first attempt at recording a historical monument during the tour of 1833, he was mistaken. The abbey ruins, which stand near Dover, would not have been accessible to him while the family awaited embarkation at Dover for the Continent, since Ruskin's cousin, Mary Richardson, makes clear in her travel diary that the family retired almost immediately on arrival in the town and departed for the steam packet early in the morning (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 1). It is possible that Ruskin had time to sketch the abbey on the return passage through Dover in September--the family's movements at that stage are unknown, since neither Mary's journal nor John James Ruskin's travel diary describes the Channel crossing and return home--but it is more likely that, in Fors, Ruskin simply miscalculated his age when he made the drawing. A drawing of St. Radegund's survives among the remains of the Sketchbook (1831-32), which more aptly fit the description his first sketches of remains of antiquity. The Ruskins visited Dover in both 1831 and 1832.

div.head: The Tour Sketches, the Illustrations for the "Account", and Visual Culture
div.p: The attempt to distinguish between the 1833 tour drawings and the illustrations for the "Account" is not meant to deny any relation at all between these kinds of drawings. Sketches served as the basis for vignette illustrations, a process documented in the evolution of Vignette after “Ancient Fortress and Rocky peak / Above the vale of Balstall”; and Ruskin planned additional such adaptations of his tour sketches, as he noted in the List of Proposed Additional Contents for the “Account” (Table 2, Illustrations), where in several instances he planned to use "my own" drawings to fashion an illustration (as opposed to adapting printed images by other artists). Moreover, Ruskin's creation of the tour sketches themselves cannot be separated entirely from the visual culture of travel-related publications that he explicitly imitated in the illustrations for the "Account". The influence of print culture on his tour sketching is perhaps what Ruskin means by remarking that he finished on-the-spot "outlines" with ideas "out of his head" later in the tour or at home in Herne Hill.

Later in life, Ruskin valued what he interpreted as signs of observed nature as opposed to convention in these first Continental drawings. In Praeterita, he singles out only "half-a-dozen" 1833 drawings as "worth register and preservation" for their observable landscape truth. For example, in the 1878 Fine Art Society exhibition of his own drawings, Ruskin showed an 1833 drawing or group of drawings described as "a day's sketching . . . between Arona and Domo d'Ossola on the same journey", though "finished out of my head" at some later time. This work, which came to be catalogued as Lago Maggiore and Domo dʼOssola, Ruskin considered "interesting" for its "proper economy of paper" and "weak enthusiasm"--qualities that he may have connected with his youthful engagement with print culture. What prompted him to exhibit the work in 1878, however, was its evidence of "fastening so early" on a landscape truth that he would illustrate over two decades later in a drawing for Modern Painters IV--The Rock of Arona. In Modern Painters, this drawing occurs among the chapters on "Sculpture of Mountains" to illustrate a discussion of rocky precipices. Ruskin traces the "real rock lines" that follow a "parabolic flow" in overhanging rock forms, arguing that, in nature, these parabolic lines trace a "delicate overhanging" that becomes "cautiously diminished as [the precipice] gets higher", as compared with the fantastically beetling precipices invented by Claude Lorrain and Renaissance painters, who were "fond of representing . . . overhanging of rocks with buildings on the top, and weeds drooping into the air over the edge, always thinking to get sublimity by exaggerating the projection" (Ruskin, Works, 13:505; 6:310-11 and pl. 41).

Critical treatment of the early tour sketches tends to be framed by Ruskin's own later approach, sifting factual observations from the chaff of conventionality, as in Paul H. Walton's singling out bits of "observation" amid the "timid drawing style, limited at this time by eighteenth-century conventions" (Walton, Drawings of John Ruskin, 14). Ruskin's youthful observations of nature were themselves prompted by the visual and print culture of his decade, however; and even this early, his "real" observation cannot be so starkly separated from his education in picturesque convention. In February 1834, when he received a birthday gift of William Brockedon's Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps, Ruskin could have found his sketches in Arona confirmed by Brockedon's plate Lago Maggiore. In this engraving, which Ruskin planned to copy as an illustration for the "Account" (see List of Proposed Additional Contents for the “Account”: “Maggiore”), one finds in the distance "on the borders of the lake", according to the accompanying text, "the overhanging precipice beneath which the route of the Simplon passes to Arona"; "it is difficult to pass" beneath this precipice, Brockedon comments, "without feeling an emotion of danger" (Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps, “The Pass of the Simplon”, 17, 18). In Brockedon's plate, the scene is peaceful yet dramatic, dominated by the colossal statue of St. Carlo Borromeo extending a blessing over the hills. In Ruskin's poem for this section of the "Account", he erases the statue but keeps the word "colossally", applying it to the surrounding moutainous landscape, "spirits of gigantic things / Lords of the earth and air and sky" (“It was an eve of summer mild” [“Lago Maggiore”]). While we will never know how Ruskin's proposed copy of Brockedon's plate might have adumbrated the "parabolic lines" that define precipices in Modern Painters Ruskin--or for that matter, what early observation of such forms can be found in Lago Maggiore and Domo dʼOssola, since apparently that drawing cannot be traced--the science of Ruskin's youthful observation cannot be separated from the facts and emotion related in Brockedon's text and engraving, the poetic imagery of spirits "of the earth and air and sky" drawn perhaps from Byron's Manfred, or the traveler's experiential awareness of recent history: atop the precipice above Arona stands the Rocca di Arona, a fortress owned by the Borromeo family, which in 1833 would have appeared notable for its recent reduction to a ruin by Napoleon's army in 1800.

The multiple and interpenetrating influences on Ruskin's vision are striking in “Part of the Town of Coblentz from the Northern Bank of the Moselle”. Before the Ruskins departed for the Continent, a part of this scene was already vivid to them from Samuel Prout's lithograph, Coblence. According to Praeterita, that plate was presented as the specimen print in the shop where John and John James entered their name as a chief subscriber to Prout's Facsimiles of Sketches Made in Flanders and Germany. As a regrettable loss in Ruskin's failure to complete the fair-copy "Account", he never carried through with his plan to convert this lithograph into an illustration for his work (see “Coblentz” and gloss). Just as remarkable, however, is a souvenir of Koblenz, in which the spectator is equally oriented to the scene by early Victorian visual culture, but which would have been useless as an illustration for the "Account": the viewpoint is a panorama of the medieval buildings of Koblenz that line the bank of the Moselle. On the left end, the panorama is anchored by the Gothic Schöffenhaus and the Romanesque Florinskirche--the cluster of venerable sacred and public buildings that, in Prout's lithograph, form the picturesque scene surrounding the figures going about their business on the quayside above the river. Here, picturesque detail is largely suppressed in favor of spare outline, as the panorama continues to the right, revealing the city's Romanesque Liebfrauenkirche, recognizable by its baroque Welschen hoods capping the towers; and onward to the opposite end, which is framed by the Alte Burg (Old Castle), founded in the thirteenth century; and the Balduinbrücke (Baldwin Bridge), which is connected to the castle at a right angle to the plane of the picture, spanning the Moselle. The drawing exerts Ruskin's training in linear perspective, a specialty of his drawing tutor, Charles Runciman, but it also reflects Ruskin's experience of panoramas--the most spectacular of which in the 1830s, Hornorʼs London Panorama, is mentioned in "Account" (“It was a wide and stretchy sweep” [prose]; and see The Colosseum, Hornorʼs London Panorama, and the Diorama in Regentʼs Park).

div.head: Untraced Tour Sketches and Illustrations for the "Account"
div.p: The relative scarcity of surviving 1833 drawings might not be suprising for such early drawings, were it not for the eagerness with which examples were collected and exhibited, both by Ruskin himself in his infrequent exhibitions, and by his admirers in the more numerous exhibitions following soon after his death. The exhibition of these drawings in the decade after 1900 doubtless testifies to the popularity of Ruskin's autobiography, Praeterita, in which Ruskin describes his youthful art training. More generally, however, British collecting in the last quarter of the nineteenth century was marked by a desire for biographical and bibliographical comprehensiveness, from boyhood to maturity, whether of drawings or writings (see Collecting of Modern Authors in the Late Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries). A collector of Ruskin's drawings who was apparently driven by this ambition, and whose name appears more than once in the list below, was Robert Ellis Cunliffe (ca. 1848–1902).

Two 1833–34 drawings that cannot be located—[“Watch‐tower at Andernach”], and [“The Jungfrau from Interlaken”]—are preserved in facsimile by photogravure. Since these survive in nineteenth‐century reproductions that, according to W. G. Collingwood (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:vii), preserve the originalsʼ dimensions, the Andernach drawing is listed here as a tour drawing: as reproduced, it would have been too large to have served as a vignette illustration for MS IX. The reproduction of the Interlaken (Switzerland) drawing, however, indicates an original of the appropriate size and shape for a vignette illustration, and its probable intended location in the “Account” can be identified: this photogravured vignette is therefore omitted here and instead treated in its place as a part of the "Account".

It is ironic that the originals of these photogravures vanished in a process of reproduction that, in W. G. Collingwoodʼs characterization, was driven by a desire for authenticity. According to his “Prefatory Notes on the Plates” in the 1891 edition of Ruskinʼs Poems, Collingwood along with the “publisher, engravers, and printers” was motivated by an “anxiety . . . that the plates should represent the original drawings as accurately as modern skill permits”. As a foil, Collingwood characterizes the “old standard art” of engraving used to illustrate Ruskinʼs earlier books as a “joint” project of designer and engraver, like “concerted music” performed by “players on different instruments”. An authentic solo performance by the designer was not reproducible on a mass scale; “it was never . . . [the artist and engraverʼs] intention to give the style and touch of the draughtsman, his separate individuality, his momentary mood, as shown in the very material and handling of the original sketch”. Now this authentic individuality had come within reach of reproducibility, it seemed, with the invention “of modern photographic engraving”, which Collingwood regards as an attempt “to reproduce the master, to facsimile the authentic document”. The means of reproduction aligns with Collingwoodʼs biographically oriented editorial aims: “this is what we want here in such pictures as rightly illustrate a collection of Poems written in Youth, in bygone historic times, recording a famous manʼs childhood and boyhood, his first impressions and fresh ideas of the world and of life”. Photographic engraving promises to supply “genuine records of the traditional precocity which we should like to verify: some true measure of the progress which we suspect, but cannnot otherwise trace, by which genius was developed. We want to see Ruskinʼs drawings, and not engraverʼs plates” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:v).

In the 1891 Poems (large‐paper edition only, the octavo edition containing no plates), the “Prefatory Notes on the Plates” complements the “Preliminary Note on the Original MSS. of the Poems”, but the former was placed at the front of volume one, and the latter at its end, presumably because the physical witnesses of the photogravure plates were regarded as the closest possible encounter with the actuality of Ruskinʼs youth. Comparatively, the edited and printed poems placed the material manuscripts at a step removed, mediated by the editor, although some compensation was afforded by photogravure reproduction of samples of Ruskinʼs early handwriting, as well. Collingwood admits that “no reproduction can be quite the same thing as an original, if the original owe any of its interest to the more subtle artistic qualities of line and tone”. The benefit of photogravure, in Collingwoodʼs mind, lay in its “mechanical reproduction by a method which, clever and charming as it is, adds nothing to . . . [the sketchesʼ] cleverness and charm”—the mechanization assuring that what was conveyed was at least purely authentic, however deficient otherwise. Collingwood evidently perceived no significant contradiction between this faith in mechanization and his admission that “Messrs. Walker and Boutallʼs photogravures” were “helped by Mr. George Allenʼs retouching” (Poems [4o, 1891], 1:vi). But what seemed comparatively to liberate reproduction of an artifact from human intervention in the 1890s now seems quaintly like handicraft. From a twenty‐first century perspective, the early stage of “photogravure was a hand process”; the skill incorporated the eighteenth‐century technique of aquatint, and “early attempts to print photographs in ink often included efforts to retain . . . [the] capacity to manipulate the image” through “intrusions of handwork” (Benson, The Printed Picture, 236, 232).
